Award.AwardTitle: Linear and non-linear elasticity: Study of exact relations and instabilities
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project revolves around two central themes: stability and heterogeneity of materials and structures, examining them from different perspectives. The heterogeneity can be artificial, or man-made, as in composite materials, or it can be created spontaneously by nature as in shape memory alloys or in some of the buckling patterns of cylindrical shells. In the former case the dependence of the macroscopic properties of materials on their microstructure is the subject of this study, where the goal is to uncover all instances where exact formulas can be established between the properties of constituent materials and the composite, regardless of the microstructure. Undergraduate research is an essential part of this project. In the latter case the creation of microstructure is caused by instabilities that are explained by the principle of minimum energy. Mathematically rigorous determination of whether it is possible to lower the energy of a configuration is an important question, especially when the configuration is already heterogeneous. Another important example of instability is buckling of cylindrical shells. These structures are especially interesting because theoretically predicted buckling compression can be up to five times higher than the experimentally observed one due to high sensitivity to initial imperfections. A newly developed theory of buckling, of which the investigator is a coauthor, shows promise in giving a new explanation of extreme sensitivity of the buckling load to imperfections.

The few exact relations that are known for fiber-reinforced elastic composites are scattered across the literature. The goal of this project is the creation of a complete list of all exact relations and links, providing a useful resource for mechanical engineers involved in the study and design of composite materials. Exact relations can be used as benchmarks for measuring the discrepancies between actual and ideal composites' properties, since they do not depend on the microstructure -- the least controllable variable in any composite. Another goal of this project is understanding of elastic instabilities in materials capable of undergoing martensitic phase transitions. In the presence of phase boundaries the problem of understanding the interplay between the global condition of positivity of second variation and local quasiconvexity conditions in the bulk requires new insights. Proposed examples of energy density functions with a large number of weak local minimizers can be used to understand the logical hierarchy of necessary conditions for strong local minima. Buckling of slender bodies represents a universal failure of weak local stability under compression. Axially compressed cylindrical shells are of special interest, since the classical heuristic asymptotic analysis of buckling predicts not only the value of the critical load that is some five times higher than experimentally observed, it also predicts incorrect scaling of the buckling load as a function of shell's thickness. This project examines a newly discovered mode-switching phenomenon, whereby small imperfections activate "latent" buckling modes with different scaling laws.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project "Linear and non-linear elasticity: Study of exact relations and
instabilities" has investigated several fundamental theoretical questions
related to stability in nonlinear elasticity and the role of microstructure.
The microstructure can be man-made in the context of composite materials, or it
may form naturally in materials capable of undergoing martensitic phase
transitions, like shape memory alloys. In the former case the microstructure
can be designed in order to obtain materials with desired properties, which
cannot be found in nature, in the latter it signals the onset of highly
nonlinear and often unusual behavior.

One of the projects aimed at a deeper understanding of the effective
properties of fiber-reinforced elastic composites, which are commonly used in
industry. For example, injecting carbon fibers into epoxy is a widely used
method for creating strong and lightweight materials. Steel-reinforced
concrete is another example. As technology gets better at controlling the
microstructure of composites it becomes more important than ever to have a
better understanding of its influence on the overall, or effective properties
of such materials. The main idea of the project was to identify all special
cases, where the microstructure has no effect on one or more effective
parameters of composites. There is a theory developed by the PI and his
collaborators that makes all such cases eminently identifiable. In the case of
fiber-reinforced elastic composites the amount of work was immense. As a
consequence, the full project, which has just been completed, spanned 6 years
and provided many opportunities for education and training of students on both
undergraduate and graduate level. During the current funding period 4
undergraduate and 1 graduate student have been involved in research on this
project. The final outcome is a large, but manageable, list of highly
nontrivial facts about effective behavior of fiber-reinforced elastic
composites with hundreds of ways of combining several of them.  This kind of
information can be used by composite designers and manufacturers to make novel
materials or accelerate their development.

The second theme addressed in the project was instability. One commonly
encountered type of instability is buckling. In his prior work, the PI and his
collaborator Lev Truskinovsky developed a general theory of buckling of
slender structures. The theory, applied to the buckling of cylindrical shells
revealed that random perturbations of stress in the body would lead to a
different scaling of the buckling load as a function of shell thickness.
Indeed, the classical formula predicts a buckling load 4 to 5 times
larger than observed in experiments. While it is universally agreed that this
happens because the buckling stress is extremely sensitive to imperfections of
load and shape, the exact mechanisms of this sensitivity (which is absent in
plates and rods) is not well-understood on a fundamental theoretical level.
The PI in collaboration with Davit Harutyunyan (PI's former postdoc) are
making progress in this directions. During the project's period they
understood that imperfections of shape might not be the main mechanism of
imperfection sensitivity, since small shape variations actually decrease the
shell's susceptibility to buckling, lessening the possible concurrent effect of
rearrangement of the structure of stress tensor. A new understanding that is
emerging from this research is that compressed cylindrical shells form a
boundary layer in the prebuckled state, producing compressive hoop stresses
that lead to buckling at much lower compressive loads.

Shape memory alloys, often called smart materials, can accommodate large
strains, not through plastic deformation that signifies internal damage, but
through phase transformations, whereby interatomic distances change in an
organized way, creating a different crystal lattice. Such phase transitions
are modeled variationally, by means of highly non-convex energies with
multiple local minima, corresponding to different martensitic phases. The
mathematical theory of minimization of such energies has been developed
relatively recently, and still has many fundamental unanswered questions. The
project exploited a new connection discovered earlier by the PI and his
collaborators between the onset of instability in a pure phase and
microstructure observed after phase transition. The elastic strain on each
phase boundary must necessarily correspond to a threshold strain at which a
phase transformation will occur in a pure phase. And conversely, stability of
a pure phase can be effectively tested by variations constructed on the basis
of an equilibrium phase boundary, resulting in algebraic stability conditions
that can be relatively easily verified for most nonlinear materials. By
contrast the exact theoretical values of threshold stresses cannot be
practically computed, aside from a few specific simple energies. In addition
to discovering new simple necessary conditions of stability, the PI and his
collaborators have realized that one can try to obtain a complete list of such
conditions for all energies in general. This is the subject of the new
research project. In a surprising synergistic collision of research directions
the PI has used theory of exact relations for composites in order to construct
an energy density of a hypothetical material, whose instabilities cannot be
manifested by phase transitions, since boundaries between phases cannot be
formed. To date there was only a single example of such energies. The new
example possesses a lot of symmetries and is surprisingly beautiful. This is a
theoretical advance in the subject of Calculus of Variations.
